awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer undergraduate research internships in ocean ecology, biogeochemistry, physical oceanography, and marine geology and geophysics in the CEOAS at OSU
awd_abstract_narration:
Oregon State University will host a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program at its main campus in Corvallis, OR that will support ten undergraduate interns. Interns will be mentored by faculty at the OSU College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences (CEOAS). This REU Site offers research experiences in physics of ocean circulation, ocean ecology and elemental cycling, and marine geology and geophysics. The objectives of the REU program are to:
1) provide students the highest quality research experience in ocean science and an understanding of its interdisciplinary nature;
2) provide students with a professional development and training opportunity facilitating persistence and retention in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) career pathways; and
3) increase access to and participation in ocean sciences in under-represented groups through targeted recruitment efforts at regional community colleges and four-year colleges and non-research universities serving underrepresented groups.

REU students in CEOAS are plugged into major research centers, institutes, and initiatives and have access to premier facilities including: the Regional Class Research Vessels (RCRV) project; the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI), which deploys and maintains the Endurance Array in the northeast Pacific; the Marine and Geology Repository (MGR), which curates core collections from the Antarctic and Southern Ocean, North Pacific, and elsewhere; PacWave, which is building the first grid connecting wave energy testing facility in the U.S.; and OSU’s Marine Studies Initiative. The program includes professional development seminars and fieldtrips. Prior interns have participated in research cruises on the R/V Elakha (for coastal and estuarine sampling) , R/V Oceanus, and other UNOLS and NOAA fleet vessels (for multi-week cruises world-wide). The first of the RCRVs, the R/V Taani, will continue and build upon the tradition of intern participation in seagoing research once delivered to OSU.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site offers undergraduate research experiences in physical oceanography, ocean ecology and biogeochemistry, and marine geology and geophysics to students from backgrounds underrepresented in ocean sciences or attending two or four year colleges with limited opportunities to engage in ocean sciences research. The breadth of this program underlies the interdisciplinary nature of oceanography and an active cohort of students engaged in diverse ocean science research areas creates a collective educational experience beneficial to all participants. The objectives of our REU program are to: 1) provide students the highest quality research experience in ocean science and an understanding of its interdisciplinary nature; 2) provide students with a professional development and training opportunity facilitating persistence and retention in STEM; and 3) increase access to and participation in ocean sciences in under-represented groups through targeted recruitment efforts at regional community colleges and four-year colleges and non-research universities serving underrepresented groups. During this one-year funding cycle, a total of 127 applications were collected for this summer internship program and 16 students participated in the program, eleven of whom were supported by this grant and five supported through other funding. Six of the eleven participating students funded on this grant are from backgrounds under-represented in ocean sciences, and eight attend non-research universities with limited opportunities to engage in ocean sciences research.

Intellectual Merit: Broad-based interdisciplinary research in ocean sciences of the type conducted at this REU Site a) improves our understanding of the physical, biological, chemical, and geological processes that govern the functioning of our oceans and the basins that contain them; b) delineate interactions and feedbacks between the ocean and other aspects of the Earth system (biosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and climate); and c) address issues facing our oceans of societal interest and relevance. Student research projects in summer 2022 included:

  • Reconstruction of ancient Mongol and modern lead pollution in Lake Erhai, China
  • Lithostratigraphic boundaries in the northern Washington margin recording the retreat of the Cordilleran Ice Sheet
  • Linking 12,000 years of climate to changing salinity and hypoxia in the Northeast Pacific using foraminiferal stable isotopes
  • Evaluating the influence of coastal ocean waters on the Yaquina Bay estuary
  • Analysis of AC-S (spectrophotometer) proxies for ecosystem variables using the OOI Endurance Array off the coasts of Oregon and Washington
  • Reconstructing Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation during Heinrich Stadial 1 using carbon isotopes
  • Refined early Cambrian small shelly fossil first appearances based on dynamic time warping alignments of δ13Ccarbonate sequences
  • The impact of phycosphere bacteria on diatom growth under iron-limiting conditions
  • Chlorophyll measurements through space and time in the Yaquina Bay estuary
  • Investigating the structure of microbial communities in freshwater and sediments where salmon spawn
  • Do ocean currents accelerate or decelerate the disintegration of ice shelves?: Conclusions from a z-coordinate model of ocean circulation

 

Broader Impacts: Undergraduate research engagement offers a transformative experience in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education and plays a key role in meeting the nation?s STEM workforce needs. The impacts of this REU Site include increased access to research experiences in ocean sciences for students attending institutions without ocean sciences programs or lacking access to research facilities and infrastructure, increased participation in ocean sciences amongst historically underrepresented groups; increased student confidence, success, retention, and persistence in STEM degree fields; and student professional development and training in transferrable skills that are useful across a broad range of STEM career pathways including written and oral communication skills, analytical methods, data management, analysis, and archival, collaboration and networking. Since 2007 this REU Site program has funded 156 students while broadening access to and participation in ocean sciences with 30% of the students from under-represented minorities and 52% from non-research universities and two and four-year colleges, while promoting persistence in STEM fields with 96% of past participants in STEM careers or continuing to pursue STEM degrees, including graduate degrees.
